title: –í JSW –Ω–µ—Ç —Å–æ–≥–ª–∞—à–µ–Ω–∏—è. –ì–æ—Ä–Ω—è–∫–∏ –≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤—è—Ç—Å—è –∫ –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–µ—Å—Ç—É
title_en: There is no agreement in JSW. Miners are preparing for a protest
summary_en:
Another mediation meeting on wage increases between the trade unions and the company's board of directors ended without an agreement.
The miners announced a protest action due to the lack of progress in negotiations on a wage increase in 2024.
The size of the salary budget at the Yastshemba Coal Company remains a matter of dispute between the trade unions and the company's management.
A mediator was needed for the last two rounds of negotiations, which took place on May 27 and June 10.
The changes in the JSW board occurred as a result of the change of power in Poland.
The trade union side considers the proposal of the board of directors to be an actual reduction in wages.
The issue of the salary fund is key to understanding the dispute in JSW.
Negotiations on a salary increase at JSW in 2024 began last year.

title: –ò—Å–ª–∞–Ω–¥—Å–∫–∏–π —Ä–∞–±–æ—á–∏–π –∑–∞—è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç –æ–± —É–≥—Ä–æ–∑–∞—Ö –≤ —Å–≤–æ–π –∞–¥—Ä–µ—Å –≤ —Å–≤—è–∑–∏ —Å –ø–ª–∞–Ω–∞–º–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∏
title_en: An Icelandic worker claims threats against himself in connection with plans for a strike
summary_en:
A former employee from Iceland told the court about threats of legal action against her property from the owner of Irish shops.
She informed the Labor Relations Commission about a series of late-night messages from a businessman accusing the union of dirty play and seeking to attack him personally.
The employee stated that the businessman subjected her to "harassment and harassment" due to the fact that she was a member of the sellers' union.
She also informed the court of further punishments in connection with the strike of employees of the Icelandic store in Kuloka.
The employee became the manager of the workshop when a branch of the Independent Workers' Union was formed at their workplace.
She spoke about the problems with wages and the strike, which Metron took a position considering illegal.
The businessman threatened to sue IWU and the employee if they did not pay.

title: ‚Äò–ú—ã –Ω–µ –æ—Ç—Å—Ç—É–ø–∞–µ–º": –∞–º–µ—Ä–∏–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏–µ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–Ω–∏–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç–æ–≤—ã—Ö –º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω–æ–≤ —É—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫—É –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –ö—Ä–æ–≥–µ—Ä–∞
title_en: ‚ÄòWe are not backing down': American grocery store workers go on strike against Kroger
summary_en:
About 6,000 grocery store workers are planning to go on strike after the expiration of a union contract with the Food 4 Less chain.
The contract with United Food and Commercial Workers expired on Saturday.
The workers are fighting for fair wages comparable to other grocery stores in the area, as well as increased security and staffing.
Employees are unhappy with how Food 4 Less treated them during the negotiation process.
Several union members from Covid-19 lost family members, despite the fact that grocery chains showed a sharp increase in profits.
Kroger reported a profit of $3.1 billion in 2023 and more than $4.1 billion in 2022.
Workers criticize pay differences and Kroger's statements in support of diversity and inclusivity.
A Kroger employee survey found that 14% are homeless or have experienced homelessness, and nearly two-thirds reported that they do not earn enough money each month to cover basic expenses.

title: –ü—Ä–µ–¥—É–ø—Ä–µ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∞—è –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∞: –¥–æ–∫–µ—Ä—ã –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—â–∞—é—Ç —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—É –≤ –ë—Ä–µ–º–µ—Ä—Ö–∞—Ñ–µ–Ω–µ
title_en: Warning strike: dockers stop work in Bremerhaven
summary_en:
Workers in Bremerhaven have paralyzed the work of the port due to a warning strike organized by the Verdi trade union.
The strike is scheduled for 22:00 until the end of the late shift.
The union wants to increase pressure on employers with a strike after an inconclusive second round of negotiations with the Central Association of German Port Companies (ZDS).
About 11,000 employees are involved in the negotiations.
In Hamburg, workers at seaports have already stopped working, and on Tuesday the port of Neustadt in Bremen was affected.
Verdi demands an increase in hourly wages and an increase in shift fees.
The Central Association of German Port Companies has proposed a 2.5 percent wage increase by June 1.
The third round of negotiations is scheduled for April 17 and 18, and the meeting is scheduled for June in Hamburg.

title: –ü–µ—Ä–µ–¥ –ö–æ–Ω–≥—Ä–µ—Å—Å–æ–º –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞—Å—å –º–æ–±–∏–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è –ø–∏–∫–µ—Ç—á–∏–∫–æ–≤, –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ—Å–æ—é–∑–æ–≤ –∏ –æ–±—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –æ—Ä–≥–∞–Ω–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–π –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –ó–∞–∫–æ–Ω–∞ –æ–± –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ö
title_en: Before the Congress, the mobilization of picketers, trade unions and public organizations against the Law on the Basics began
summary_en:
Public organizations, picketers and trade unions are mobilizing against the Basic Law being debated in the Senate.
The purpose of the action is to put pressure on parliamentarians to reject the initiative of the executive branch.
The organizers promise a mass action and promise to "challenge" the deployment of federal forces.
The surroundings of the Legislative Palace are fenced off, and security inside the Congress and on the approaches to it is strengthened.
Four federal forces are involved in the operation, supported by infantry, special forces and motorized brigades.
The organizers plan to set up camp or hold a vigil if the debate drags on and there is no fourth intermission.
Picketers and public movements will travel to the Congress Square in front of the Parliament by public transport.

title: –ö–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω–∏—è –∏–∑ –ù–∞–≤–∞—Ä—Ä—ã —Å 80 —Å–æ—Ç—Ä—É–¥–Ω–∏–∫–∞–º–∏ –≤–æ–∑–≤—Ä–∞—â–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—É –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ 112 –¥–Ω–µ–π –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∏
title_en: Navarre-based company with 80 employees returns to work after 112 days of strike
summary_en:
Lozys Pharmaceuticals staff returned to work after a four-month strike.
The agreement improves the working and living conditions of the 80 people who make up the staff.
ELA (all 5 representatives of the committee) will sign a 24-hour reduction in the working day, an increase in excess of CPI and other improvements.
In the spring of 2023, trade union elections were held at the enterprise for the first time, and ELA received five representatives.
Since then, attempts have been made to conclude a corporate agreement, but no agreement has been reached.
On February 20 of this year, the team decided to go on strike, which lasted 112 days.
During the strike, numerous demonstrations and rallies took place in Elizondo in front of the Parliament of Navarre.
ELA gives a positive assessment of both the agreement and the strike, emphasizing the strength and solidarity of the workers.

title: –ß–∏—Å–ª–æ —Ü–µ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–≤ —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø–æ–¥ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂–µ–π –≤ –í–µ–Ω–µ—Å—É—ç–ª–µ, –≥–¥–µ –∑–∞–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–æ–¥—è—Ç –≥–æ–ª–æ–¥–æ–≤–∫—É, —É–≤–µ–ª–∏—á–∏–ª–æ—Å—å –¥–æ 51
title_en: The number of detention centers in Venezuela where prisoners are on hunger strike has increased to 51
summary_en:
16 detention centers have joined a prison hunger strike in Venezuela.
The total number of prisons and police stations increased to 51 with prisoner protests.
The hunger strike has spread to Caracas and 17 of the country's 23 states, while there have been no reports of protests in the other six regions.
Thousands of prisoners continue to strike, the regime of Nicolas Maduro has not spoken out about this.
The Ministry of Penitentiary Services did not comment on the strike and shared the images via X.
Women deprived of their liberty at the National Institute for Women's Orientation also joined the strike.
A report by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights called the situation of persons deprived of their liberty in Venezuela "one of the most serious in the region."
Overcrowding in prisons can be a form of cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.

title: –ü—Ä–æ—Ñ—Å–æ—é–∑—ã: —Ä–µ–≥—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ —Ç–∞—Ä–∏—Ñ–æ–≤ –≤ —Ä–æ–∑–Ω–∏—á–Ω–æ–π —Ç–æ—Ä–≥–æ–≤–ª–µ –ú–µ–∫–ª–µ–Ω–±—É—Ä–≥-–ü–µ—Ä–µ–¥–Ω—è—è –ü–æ–º–µ—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—è
title_en: Trade unions: regulation of tariffs in retail trade Mecklenburg-Vorpommern
summary_en:
Tariff partners in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern are taking steps to pay salaries to 55,000 employees.
The fifth round of negotiations will resume on Wednesday in Gyustrov after a six-month break.
Workers have repeatedly declared precautionary strikes in support of their demands.
The chances of reaching an agreement are high.
In May, a phased wage increase was agreed in Hamburg and Schleswig-Holstein.
Wages were increased retroactively by 5.3 percent as of October 2023 and by another 4.7 percent as of May 2024.
During the third tariff year, starting in May 2025, wages should be increased by a fixed amount of 40 euros, and then by another 1.8 percent.
Employees receive a bonus of 1,000 euros to compensate for inflation, and the annual contribution to collective pension planning increases from 300 euros to 420 euros.

title: –†–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–∏ –≤–µ–Ω–µ—Å—É—ç–ª—å—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∑–∞–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–∏–∑—ã–≤–∞—é—Ç –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–æ "–±—ã—Å—Ç—Ä–æ" —Ä–µ—à–∏—Ç—å –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—É —Ç—é—Ä–µ–º–Ω–æ–π –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∏
title_en: Relatives of Venezuelan prisoners urge the government to "quickly" solve the problem of the prison strike
summary_en:
Relatives of prisoners in Venezuela are calling on the government to end a hunger strike carried out by thousands of prisoners in protest at the delay in the trial.
The protests spanned 51 institutions, from prisons to police stations, and affected an estimated 50,000 prisoners.
Dozens of people sang the national anthem and chanted slogans in front of the courthouses, calling on the executive branch to respond to complaints from starving prisoners.
About ten wives, mothers and daughters of prisoners were warned about the deterioration of the prisoners' health due to the strike, which has already lasted more than 72 hours.
The protests have spread to at least 17 of the country's 23 states, according to Tuesday's figures released by OVP.
The Ministry of Penitentiary Service did not comment on the strike, but instead shared images via X, where prisoners are shown together with medical staff and visits are reported "as part of the guarantee of the human rights of prisoners in the country."

title: –£—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è –ö–æ–ª—É–º–±–∏–∏ –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∏ –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫—É –≤ –∑–Ω–∞–∫ –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–∞ –æ–± –æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–∏, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π –ø—Ä–æ–¥–≤–∏–≥–∞–µ—Ç –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–æ
title_en: Teachers in Colombia have started a strike to protest against the education law promoted by the government
summary_en:
Teachers and teachers in Colombia have begun a strike against the Education Law being debated in Congress.
Hundreds of people protested, calling for the repeal of the law, which could harm students, teachers and education in general.
A protest march has begun in Bogota and other unions supporting the mobilization are expected to arrive.
Fecode, the main education workers' union, opposes the law and calls on the Senate, the House of Representatives and society to protect Colombian public education.
Fecode criticizes the bill for taking into account student academic performance as a variable when evaluating professors for promotion.
The Fecode strike marks a distancing from the government of President Gustavo Petro, as the union had previously supported him.

title_en: ‚ÄúI have never raised the issue of reprisals,‚Äù the Minister of Labor says in connection with the accusations of trade unions from this portfolio claiming that the strike is prohibited
summary_en:
The workers' union expressed dissatisfaction with the administration, considering that they were not given the opportunity to be heard in the labor process.
Claims are filed in accordance with the procedure established by law, which is considered the right of every employee.
The main complaint of the trade union is that the labor portfolio was not given the opportunity to express concerns to the national government.
The Government has committed itself to ensuring fair and transparent labor processes in accordance with constitutional guarantees.
The authorities insist that they are ready to listen and meet the demands of the workers.
The unions of the Ministry of Labor have sent a letter to the Minister and other officials condemning actions that harm their right to strike.
The Ministry of Labor announced the approval of one of the demands of the trade unions and asked the striking officials to cancel the strike.

title: –ù–æ–≤—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –ø–µ–Ω—Å–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–π —Ä–µ—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—ã –ü–µ—Ç—Ä–æ: –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ—Å–æ—é–∑ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ—Å–æ—é–∑–æ–≤ –∑–∞—è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç, —á—Ç–æ –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω–∏—è –Ω–µ –≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∞, –∏ —Ä–∞—Å—Å–º–∞—Ç—Ä–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å –æ–±—ä—è–≤–∏—Ç—å –∑–∞–±–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤–∫—É
title_en: New problems of Petro's pension reform: the union of trade unions says that the company is not ready and is considering going on strike
summary_en:
Trade unions have expressed concern about unsatisfied demands in connection with pension reform.
The president of the Trade Union of Employees of Enterprises (Sintracolpen) stated that the company will not be able to carry out reform without resolving petitions.
Sintracolpen members are at the site in front of the Colpensiones headquarters in Bogota, expressing concern about the implementation of the reform.
A key problem for Sintracolpen is the lack of technological improvements to cope with the expected increase in workload.
The union demands an increase in wages and a solution to structural problems in the management of positions.
The president of Colpensiones has not entered into a dialogue with the union since August 2023, increasing frustration among union members.
If the pension reform is not adopted by June 20, it will collapse, and the government of President Gustavo Petro is doing everything possible to avoid such a scenario.

title: –í–µ–Ω–µ—Å—É—ç–ª—å—Å–∫–∏–µ –∑–∞–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –æ–±—ä—è–≤–∏–ª–∏ –≥–æ–ª–æ–¥–æ–≤–∫—É –∏–∑-–∑–∞ –∑–∞–¥–µ—Ä–∂–µ–∫ –≤ –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–æ—Å—É–¥–∏—è –∏ –ø–ª–æ—Ö–∏—Ö —É—Å–ª–æ–≤–∏–π —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∞–Ω–∏—è
title_en: Venezuelan prisoners have gone on hunger strike due to delays in the administration of justice and poor conditions of detention
summary_en:
Prisoners in Venezuela have gone on hunger strike due to delays in the administration of justice and poor conditions of detention.
The mass protest revealed serious flaws in the Venezuelan judicial system, which international bodies had warned about.
The women began protests demanding the release of prisoners with at least 50% of their sentences served and other discounts on sentences.
The strike continues to spread to more prisoners, wives, mothers, sisters and other relatives demonstrated in front of the courthouse in Caracas on Wednesday.
President Nicolas Maduro has announced his intention to end corruption in prisons and build a new administration and prison regime.
The dismissal of the minister does not solve the structural problem, and the judicial revolution has not led to significant results.
The government focused on intervening in prisons, but the gang leaders managed to escape before the authorities arrived.
At the height of the strike, there were reports of attacks on prisoners by security agencies and the death of a prisoner due to lack of medical care.

title: "–ú–Ω–µ –≤—Å–µ —Ä–∞–≤–Ω–æ, —á—Ç–æ —É–º–µ—Ä–µ—Ç—å –∑–¥–µ—Å—å": –¥–≤–æ–µ –ø–æ–∂–∞—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö —É–∂–µ 15 –¥–Ω–µ–π –æ–±—ä—è–≤–ª—è—é—Ç –≥–æ–ª–æ–¥–æ–≤–∫—É –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –ê—é—Å–æ –∏ –≥–æ—Ä–æ–¥—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ —Å–æ–≤–µ—Ç–∞ –õ–µ–≥–∞–Ω–µ—Å–∞
title_en: "I don't care if I die here": two firefighters have been on hunger strike for 15 days against Ayuso and the Leganes City Council
summary_en:
Two firefighters, Charles Rodriguez and Ruben Agudo, have been paid just over 700 euros per month for three years.
They are listed as employees who are in a state of forced leave due to many administrative errors.
Firefighters have been on hunger strike for 15 days and 14 nights in front of the Madrid City Hall, demanding their seats be returned.
They claim that in other municipalities, the community of Madrid has allowed corps personnel to remain under municipal administration.
The Leganes City Council acknowledges that the local government is "trying to mediate," even though the ball is in the hands of the Madrid community.
Firefighters assure that in other municipalities, the community of Madrid has indeed allowed corps personnel to remain under municipal control.
